# Results {#results}

## CX3CL1/CX3CR1 signaling in the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala

Considering CX3CR1 implication in anxiety as well as its relatively high expression in the amygdala, the neurophysiological consequences, such as neuronal activity, synaptic transmission, and long-term potentiation, were explored. 

### CX3CR1 activation reduces the excitability of principal neurons in the rat BLA

First, the intrinsic firing properties of principal cells, the most numerous neurons in the BLA,  were assessed through whole-cell patch-clamp recordings, evoking action potentials in response to somatic current injection.

The analysis revealed that following CX3CL1 treatment, the action potential's threshold was significantly more depolarized, as compared to baseline (from `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Hence, a higher current injection is needed to induce neuronal firing, suggesting that pyramidal-like neurons may be less excitable in the presence of CX3CL1.
As shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)d1), the gain (slope) remained unchanged (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(gain)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(gain), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)`, CX3CL1(2nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(gain)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(gain), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfigall1) and \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfigall2) in the Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1membraneappendix)).

Similar effects were observed in higher dose (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, CX3CL1(5nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_5nM_BLA_stat_tres`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
The two approaches were used to confirm whether CX3CL1-induced reduction in excitability is dependent on the CX3CL1 receptor, CX3CR1.
First, before recordings, a subset of slices was incubated with antibodies against CX3CR1 (2ng/ml).
Under such experimental conditions, the CX3CL1-induced reduction in principal cells' excitability was not statistically significant; however, there still was a proportion of neurons responding with an increased action potential threshold (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Notably, slices used in this study were 300 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m thin, and the antibody penetration was limited to (`r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m [@fogarty_2013]. 
To this end, another subset of experiments was performed using a pharmacological approach with AZD8797 to inhibit CX3CR1 [@ridderstadwollberg_2014].

As shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), AZD8797 prevented the CX3CL1-induced decrease in principal cells' excitability, manifested as an increased action potential threshold, and thereby additionally confirmed CX3CR1 mediation in the observed effect (`r CX3CL1_azdfrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`).

Of note, AZD9787 did not affect this parameter when applied alone (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd)a, baseline in DMSO = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, AZD8797(10`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_azda_BLA_stat_tres`). 

Since it is well-known that the CX3CR1 receptor is mostly expressed on microglia, next, the possible involvement of this type of glial cells in mediating CX3CL1-induced reduction of PCs excitability was investigated.<!-- citations-->
For this reason, the slices were pretreated with 100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M minocycline, a tetracycline-like antibiotic known to inhibit microglial activation, before and during CX3CL1 application.
As presented in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), the inhibition of microglial activity also diminished the CX3CL1-triggered effect on the action potential threshold (`r CX3CL1_minofrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`).
In contrast, the minocycline applied alone increased the excitability of PCs (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, minocycline (100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_minoa_BLA_stat_tres`, Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd)). 
Thus, this finding highlights the potential importance of microglial functions in regulating the activity of neurons in the BLA. 

Finally, since it is increasingly evident that a heterogeneous group of interneurons tightly controls the activity of principal cells in the BLA  (see Introduction \@ref(BLA)), it was investigated whether blocking GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors would eliminate this depressing effect on PCs' firing by CX3CL1.<!--dawki.--> 
For this reason, recordings were made with the additional presence of the picrotoxin (100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) and CGP52432 (10`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M), respectively.
As expected, the CX3CL1 effect was fully abolished when the GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors were blocked (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, CX3CL1 (2nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_gabafrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Thus, these data suggest that CX3CL1 reduced principal cells' firing *via* a CX3CR1-, microglia-, and interneuron-dependent manner.<!-- cooperate?-->

Having established a significant CX3CL1-modulated suppression of principal cells’ firing, the main group of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, the potential contribution of CX3CL1 on the modulation of the excitatory transmission in this area was measured.
Spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents (sEPSCs) were recorded *via* whole-cell patch-clamp recordings (held at −70 mV). 

All measured parameters of excitatory synaptic transmission before and after applying CX3CL1, AZD8797, and minocycline are described in detail in Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sEPSCappendix), summarized in Table 7.2, and illustrated in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSCfigall).
Compared to the control, CX3CL1 in both measured concentrations (2nM and 5nM) had a negligible effect on the median value of the amplitude, frequency, and kinetics of sEPSCs.
However, although statistically not significant, a proportion of neurons (`r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50%) reacted with a decreased frequency of excitatory synaptic currents (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSC)a).

Furthermore, similar to previous findings, in addition to upregulated excitability, minocycline alone also altered sEPSC kinetics by increasing both their rise time from `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` ms, n = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_sEPSC_mino_BLA_stat_sEPSC_rt`) and 
decay time from `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` ms, n = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_sEPSC_mino_BLA_stat_sEPSC_dt`)(Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSC)b1-b3).
Thus, these observations suggest that microglia may be one of the key contributors regulating excitatory drive in the BLA.<!-- Our findings overall highlight microglia and its receptor CX3CR1 as key contributors in regulation of social behavioral adaptation to chronic stress.-->

These observations showed that the CX3CL1-induced downregulation of principal cells' excitability was also associated with GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors (see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)).
This is in line with mounting evidence pointing to local interneurons as key regulators of the activity of pyramidal-like neurons (see Introduction \@ref(BLA)).
Hence, the possible influence of CX3CL1 on the inhibitory transmission onto BLA PCs was next explored in *in vitro* slices.
Cells were clamped at 0 mV to record the spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents (sIPSCs).
The representative traces of sIPSCs in the absence (baseline) and presence of CX3CL1 (2 and 5nM) are shown in Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC).
At 2nM, CX3CL1 was ineffective in changing any of the sIPSCs measured parameters (for details, see Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix)), whereas higher concentration (5nM) of CX3CL1 robustly<!--markedly--> reduced the GABAergic transmission onto principal cells in the BLA by decreasing the median frequency from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` Hz and the median amplitude from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Amplitude)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Amplitude), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Amplitude)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Amplitude), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` pA, respectively, compared to the baseline.
Further analysis of IPSCs kinetics showed that the median rise times and decay times<!--and mIPSCs--> remained unchanged (from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms and from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms, respectively), as reported by data in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSCappendixfig) in Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix). 

Similarly to what was observed in experiments assessing PCs' excitability, this drastic reduction of GABAergic synaptic transmission followed by CX3CL1 treatment was eliminated by both AZD8797 and minocycline.
In particular, following CX3CL1(5nM) application, the presence of the CX3CR1 inhibitor and the blocker of microglial activity resulted in the `r round(round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)/round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")``r round((round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)) / (round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)), digits = 2)` % and `r round(round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)/round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` 
`r round((round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)) / (round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline + \nCX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)), digits = 2)` % of the median frequency during baseline, respectively.
These findings indicate a functional involvement of CX3CR1 and microglia in the modulation of BLA GABAergic transmission (Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC)).

In addition, to determine if a decrease in sIPSC frequency by CX3CL1 was due to a change in the spontaneous action potential firing in the slice, the TTX (500nM) was used to block neuronal firing.
The mIPSC amplitude, frequency, and kinetics were measured before and after the CX3CL1 application (clamped at 0 mV).
No changes in these parameters were found between baseline and CX3CL1-applied recordings (see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC)b and c, mIPSC frequency: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_freq`, mIPSC amplitude: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_amp`).
Hence, data presented here suggest that CX3CL1 reduces GABA release at the local BLA synapses, probably by depression of the spontaneous firing of local interneurons.
Notably, the decreased median amplitude of sIPSCs suggests that this signaling molecule might also modulate synapses *via* a postsynaptic mechanism. 
Moreover, this inhibition of GABAergic transmission by 5nM CX3CL1 was mediated by both CX3CR1 and microglia.

### CX3CL1 impairs the long-term potentiation in the BLA


Considering studies indicating CX3CL1 involvement in memory, along with presented here depression of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, the next step was to gain insights into how CX3CL1 modulates the BLA network activity.
To this end, extracellular recordings were employed.
The amplitude of field potentials, short-term plasticity, and long-term potentiation were assessed.
At the beginning of each experiment, the I/O curves were determined, as shown in Figure \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)a. 
No significant differences were evident between the input–output curves of FPs recorded from the control and CX3CL1-induced slices (<!--number of slices = uzupełnić-->F (3, 41) = 0.4,	P=0.75, ANOVA)<!--jaka? mixed? two-way?-->.
It indicates that CX3CL1 did not modulate the baseline excitatory activity in the BLA under our experimental conditions.
The paired-pulse ratio, a form of short-term plasticity sensitive mainly to presynaptic changes [@stuart_1991], was also investigated.
<!-- jedno zdanie że external capsule input stimulation led to PPF in all experiments -->
This parameter also remained unaffected by CX3CL1 treatment (<!--number of slices = uzupełnić,-->H= 3.930, p = 0.27, Kruskal-Wallis test; see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)b), suggesting CX3CL1 action in the BLA is rather not presynaptic.

Notably, upon application of Theta Burst Stimulation (TBS), external capsule-evoked field potentials in the BLA were effectively potentiated in the control slices, but not in the slices treated with CX3CL1, as revealed by a significant decrease measured by the comparison of average potentiation before and after LTP induction (F(2, 26) = 156.6, p < 0.001, ANOVA and Tukey's post hoc test<!--jaka?-->; see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)c).
However, the additional presence of AZD8797, CX3CR1 antagonist, did not fully abolish this effect (F(2, 26) = 156.6, p < 0.001, ANOVA and Tukey's post hoc test).
Together, these findings demonstrate an<!--specific--> impairment of BLA synaptic plasticity to external capsule inputs after CX3CL1 treatment.<!-- of external capsule inputs to LA/BLA.-->
Considering that one of the mechanisms of synaptic plasticity is changes in dendritic spines morphology<!--inaczej to napisać-->, the next goal was to examine whether CX3CL1 affects dendrites morphology in the amygdala.

### CX3CL1 modulated the dendritic spine morphology in cultured rat amygdala neurons

To confirm whether changes in dendritic morphology were accompanied by CX3CL1-induced impairment in the LTP, the shape of dendritic spines was analyzed.
To this end, the primary neuronal cultures were prepared from the amygdala of rat pups at P0.
Primary neuronal cultures are mainly comprised of neurons; however, the proportion of 5-7% of glia is usually observed.<!--cytowanie? --> 
To further isolate the neuronal component of CX3CL1-mediated neuromodulation in the amygdala, the medium was supplemented with mitotic inhibition (cytarabine (AraC)) in a subset of neuronal cultures. 
It is an inhibitor of uncontrolled proliferation of non-neuronal cells without affecting neuronal survival or neurite outgrowth, or soma diameter [@schwieger_2016].
Thus, under such conditions, the glial involvement on dendritic spine parameters was further reduced without affecting neuronal viability. 

The proper generation and maturation of dendritic spines are crucial for regulating synaptic transmission, plasticity, and formation of neuronal circuits.<!--dać publikacje zespołu Jakuba-->
Fig. \@ref(fig:spinesss) shows representative images of dendritic fragments of cultured neurons during baseline (a) and after 20 minutes of CX3CL1 application (b).<!--poprawić??-->
The CX3CL1 application in the standard medium did not elicit any statistically significant changes, although there is a trend towards the increased width of dendritic spines.
Interestingly, when neurons were supplemented with AraC, further reducing the glial population, the CX3CL1 led to more prominent changes, manifested as decreased width and length of dendritic spines, and therefore significantly reducing the head/length ratio.
This parameter implies the more immature dendritic morphology.
Thus, these observations suggest that CX3CL1 is able to modulate morphological changes of dendritic spines.
Moreover, given that even a slight reduction in the number of glial cells in almost entirely ( 94-95%) neuronal cultures led to more distinct and opposing changes, one might speculate that neuron-glia communication is a key player in observed CX3CL1-mediated actions on the dendritic spine morphology.
Finally, in accordance with the reported CX3CL1-mediated impairment in the LTP at cortico-BLA synapses, the immature morphology of dendritic spines might be linked to decreased synaptic efficacy and, thereby, decreased magnitude of synaptic potentiation.
Given that neurons from amygdala primary cultures displayed that immature phenotype when AraC was present in the medium, it raises the possibility of the glial involvement in these effects.

Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMK) has been shown to play a critical role in long-term potentiation (LTP) and emotional learning mediated by the basolateral amygdala.<!--citation?-->
This is also a critical marker of principal cells in the BLA [@mcdonald_2002a].
Results presented in this dissertation showed that CX3CL1-induced depression of principal cell's excitability and the impairment in LTP in the BLA, the immunohistochemistry used to examine the level of the expression of CX3CL1 and CX3CR1 in CAMK-II-`r knitr::asis_output("\U03B1")`-positive cells in the BLA.
As illustrated in Figure \@ref(fig:BLACX3CL1immunofig), CX3CR1 receptor was present in `r round(cx3cr1_col, digits = 2)``r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")``r round(cx3cr1_sd, digits = 2)` % of pyramidal-like neurons in the BLA.

The results regarding CX3CR1 expression in neurons, especially principal cells, were also confirmed in neuronal cultures of the amygdala.
Hence, although all of the electrophysiological effects of the CX3CL1 were prevented by minocycline, the direct action of this chemokine on neurons is also plausible.
However, as shown in Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)c1 and c2, 50% of neurons were responsive when 2nM CX3CL1 was applied, while 5nM CX3CL1 affected a larger fraction of neurons, reaching 65%. 
Thus, the immunostaining data shows that CX3CR1 expression involves a much lower subset of principal cells, suggesting that probably this CX3CL1-decreased firing of those neurons is not exclusively induced by direct activation of a CX3CR1 receptor at their membrane.
